Name: Orbencarb
Description: Orbencarb is a monothiocarbamic ester that is carbamothioic S-acid substituted by two ethyl groups at the nitrogen atom and a 2-chlorobenzyl group at the the sulfur atom. It has a role as a xenobiotic, an environmental contaminant and a herbicide. It is a member of monochlorobenzenes and a monothiocarbamic ester.

plant_translocations.content: The study on soybean plants revealed that the absorption and translocation of 14C-orbencarb increased with plant growth stages, with the highest absorption occurring in leaves and the lowest in seeds. At flowering, green seed, and mature stages, plants absorbed 0.8%, 9.3%, and 9.1% of the applied radioactivity, respectively. 14C-Orbencarb was rapidly converted into water-soluble metabolites, with major metabolites being 2-chlorobenzyl alcohol and 2-chlorobenzoic acid in free and conjugated forms, along with 2-chlorobenzylsulfonic acid and methyl 2-chlorobenzylsulfone. Minor metabolites included orbencarb sulfoxide, monodesethyl-orbencarb, didesethyl-orbencarb, orbencarb, 4-hydroxy-orbencarb, 5-hydroxy-orbencarb, N-ethyl-N-vinyl, and methyl 2-chlorobenzylsulfoxide.
plant_translocations.reference: 池田光政, 右内忠昭, & 富澤長次郎. (1986). Absorption, translocation and metabolism of orbencarb in soybean plants. Journal of Pesticide Science, 11(1), 97-110.

method.Plant Grown Condition: Soybean seeds planted 3 cm deep in unglazed pots (27 cm diameter, 23 cm height) filled with 8.5 kg of volcanic ash soil from Nagano. Initially 6 seeds per pot, thinned to 3 healthy seedlings after emergence. Grown under greenhouse conditions, maintaining suitable soil moisture.
method.Chemical Preparation: 14C-orbencarb labeled uniformly at the benzene ring, with specific activity adjusted to 2.39 mCi/mmol and radiochemical purity 99.8%. A 2850 ppm water emulsion prepared by dissolving 344.9 mg (3.2 mCi) 14C-orbencarb and 345 mg emulsifier in 120 mL water.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: For main experiment, 10 mL of the 2850 ppm 14C-orbencarb emulsion applied uniformly to soil surface immediately after seeding, followed by 20 mL water (5 kg ai/ha).
method.Other Information: Main experiment plants harvested 1, 3, 7, 12, 15, 19, 30 (flowering), 62 (green seed), and 84 (mature stage) days after seeding.

plant_translocations.content: The study on cotton plants demonstrated that the absorption and translocation of 14C-orbencarb increased over time when applied to the soil surface. Topical application to a leaf or stem of cotton seedlings resulted in the translocation of radioactivity throughout the plant. At the mature stage, 3.4% of the applied radioactivity was absorbed by the plants, with 0.1% found in the seeds and 44.6% remaining in the soil. 14C-Orbencarb was rapidly metabolized in both the cotton plants and soil, gradually transforming into water-soluble metabolites. Major metabolites included methyl 2-chlorobenzyl sulfone, monodesethyl-orbencarb, 2-chlorobenzyl alcohol, and 2-chlorophenylmethanesulfonic acid, while minor metabolites were methyl 2-chlorobenzyl sulfoxide, didesethyl-orbencarb, and 2-chlorobenzoic acid, in free or conjugated forms.
plant_translocations.reference: 池田光政, 右内忠昭, & 富澤長次郎. (1986). Absorption, translocation and metabolism of the herbicide orbencarb in cotton plant. Journal of Pesticide Science, 11(3), 379-385.

method.Plant Grown Condition: seedlings grown separately in 15 cm diameter pots until 3rd true leaf stage.
method.Chemical Preparation: 14C-orbencarb labeled uniformly on benzene ring, specific activity 2.39 mCi/mmol, 99.8% radiochemical purity. 2850 ppm water emulsion prepared by dissolving 344.9 mg (3.2 mCi) 14C-orbencarb and 345 mg non-ionic emulsifier in 120 mL water.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: 50 μL emulsion applied to entire upper surface of 1st or 3rd true leaf.
